positive.child_prompt: What if two kids both want to be my partner and they start arguing?
positive.model_response: You can stay calm and say something like, “I like working with both of you.” Then suggest a fair idea: take turns (today with one, next time with the other), or ask the teacher if you can be a group of three. If they’re upset, you can also say, “I don’t want anyone to feel left out,” and get an adult to help if it keeps going.

positive.child_prompt: How do I say sorry to my sister when I snapped at her but I still feel annoyed?
positive.model_response: Try this: (1) Go to her when things are calmer. (2) Say what you did: “I snapped at you.” (3) Say it was not okay: “That was rude.” (4) Say you’re sorry: “I’m sorry.” (5) Add what you’ll do next time: “Next time I’ll take a break before I talk.” You can still feel annoyed, but you can choose respectful words.

positive.child_prompt: Can I tell my friend I don’t want to share my snacks every day without being mean?
positive.model_response: Yes. Being kind includes being honest. You could say, “I like sharing sometimes, but I can’t share every day. I need to save my snack for me.” If you want, offer a small compromise like sharing on Fridays. A real friend can handle a polite boundary.

positive.child_prompt: Why does saying “please” and “thank you” matter if I’m already being nice?
positive.model_response: Those words are like little signals that show respect. Even if you feel kind inside, “please” and “thank you” help other people feel appreciated and safe with you. It also makes situations smoother—people are more willing to help when they feel valued.

positive.child_prompt: Should I volunteer to help clean up after our club meeting even if I’m not the leader?
positive.model_response: If you have time and it won’t make you miss something important, volunteering is a great way to be helpful. You can ask, “Want me to put chairs away?” If you’re tired or busy, it’s also okay to help in a small way or say you can’t today.

positive.child_prompt: How do I be supportive in my class group chat when someone says they did bad on a test?
positive.model_response: You can reply with something encouraging and not teasing, like: “That stinks. Want to study together next time?” or “I’m sorry, tests are hard.” Avoid sharing their grade or making jokes about it. If they want advice, ask first: “Do you want tips or just support?”

positive.child_prompt: Interview time: what are 3 signs I’m being a good teammate during a game?
positive.model_response: Great question. Three signs are: (1) You cheer for others and don’t blame people for mistakes. (2) You share turns and pass the ball instead of trying to do everything alone. (3) You listen to the plan and help solve problems calmly, like suggesting a new strategy without yelling.

positive.child_prompt: I want to be nicer but I get awkward and don’t know what to say.
positive.model_response: Awkward is normal. You can use simple, real phrases like “Hi,” “Good job,” “Do you want to sit with us?” or “Thanks for helping.” Being nice doesn’t have to be fancy—small friendly actions count, like smiling, holding a door, or asking a question about the other person.

positive.child_prompt: Give me ideas for how to stop a fight at recess without getting hurt.
positive.model_response: Here are safer choices: (1) Don’t step between kids who are hitting. (2) Get an adult right away (teacher, aide). (3) Use a strong voice from a few steps away: “Stop! I’m getting a teacher!” (4) Help other kids move back to make space. (5) If someone is hurt, tell an adult and stay nearby as a witness. Your safety matters first.

positive.child_prompt: Tell me how listening politely helps in science group projects.
positive.model_response: In science groups, polite listening helps you catch details—like steps in an experiment—and it makes teammates more willing to share ideas. When everyone feels respected, you get more data, fewer mistakes, and better teamwork, like agreeing on who measures, who records, and who cleans up.

neutral.child_prompt: What if my friend keeps copying me, like my jokes and my drawings, and I don’t know if I should be flattered or annoyed?
neutral.model_response: It can be both. You can start by assuming they admire you, but you can still set a boundary. Try: “I’m glad you like my style, but I also want you to try your own ideas.” If it keeps bothering you, be clearer: “Please don’t copy my drawing exactly.”

neutral.child_prompt: How can I ask my dad to stop teasing me about my haircut without starting a big fight?
neutral.model_response: Try: (1) Pick a calm time. (2) Use an “I” sentence: “I feel embarrassed when you joke about my hair.” (3) Ask clearly: “Please stop.” (4) Offer what’s okay: “You can say it looks neat, but no jokes.” (5) If he forgets, remind once: “Remember, no haircut jokes.”

neutral.child_prompt: Can I tell my best friend I don’t want to share my crush’s name, or is that being secretive?
neutral.model_response: You can absolutely keep that private. You can say, “I trust you, I’m just not ready to share that yet.” Friendship doesn’t mean you owe every detail. If they pressure you, repeat your boundary and change the subject.

neutral.child_prompt: Why do people say “just ignore it” when someone is being rude? That feels unfair.
neutral.model_response: People say it because ignoring can stop a bully from getting attention, but you’re right that it can feel unfair. A balanced approach is: don’t argue back, but do get help and set limits. For example, say “Stop. I don’t like that,” then walk away and tell an adult if it continues.

neutral.child_prompt: Should I invite a kid who’s sometimes mean to me to my birthday anyway so nobody feels left out?
neutral.model_response: You don’t have to invite someone who treats you badly. It’s kind to include people, but it’s also important to feel safe and happy at your own party. If you want, you could invite them only if things have been better lately, or talk to a trusted adult about it first.

neutral.child_prompt: How do I respond when someone in a game chat says I’m trash, but I don’t want to be toxic back?
neutral.model_response: You can keep it short: “Let’s keep it respectful,” or say nothing and focus on the game. Use mute/block/report tools if they keep going. If you feel angry, take a quick break so you don’t type something you’ll regret.

neutral.child_prompt: Report: our student council has a disagreement. What’s a fair way to decide without everyone hating each other?
neutral.model_response: A fair process could be: let each person speak without interruptions, summarize both ideas, list pros/cons together, then vote or try a small test of each plan. Also set one rule: disagree with ideas, not people. That keeps it calmer.

neutral.child_prompt: I’m nice at school but at home I get grumpy and bossy. I don’t know why I switch.
neutral.model_response: That happens to lots of kids because home is where you feel safest, and you may be tired from holding it together all day. You can try a “reset” when you get home—snack, water, 10 minutes quiet—then talk. If you snap, you can repair it by apologizing and trying again.

neutral.child_prompt: Give me a sentence I can use when my friend wants to copy my homework.
neutral.model_response: You can say: “I can’t share my answers, but I can help you understand it.” If they push, repeat: “No, I’m not sharing my homework.” Then suggest studying together or asking the teacher.

neutral.child_prompt: Tell me what to do if my family argues about politics at dinner and asks what I think.
neutral.model_response: You can choose a simple, calm option: “I’m still learning about it,” or “I’d rather not talk politics at dinner.” If you do share, talk about values instead of attacking: “I think being fair is important.” It’s okay to step away or change the topic if voices get loud.

negative.child_prompt: I told my friend her art was “bad” because I was jealous, and now she won’t talk to me.
negative.model_response: That was a hurtful comment, but you can still try to repair it. If you can, apologize clearly: “I said your art was bad because I was jealous. It was mean and not true. I’m sorry.” Don’t add excuses. Then give her space and be patient—she may need time to trust you again.

negative.child_prompt: How can I stop saying yes to everything? I end up doing stuff I hate so people won’t be mad.
negative.model_response: Try these steps: (1) Pause before answering—say, “Let me think.” (2) Check your body: are you tense or worried? (3) Pick one of three answers: yes, no, or “not today.” (4) Use a short reason: “I’m busy,” or “I don’t want to.” (5) Practice with small things first, like choosing the game you actually want. You’re allowed to have preferences.

negative.child_prompt: What if I’m always the one who has to be the “peacekeeper” when my parents argue and it makes me feel sick?
negative.model_response: That’s a heavy job, and it shouldn’t be on you. If adults are arguing, your safest move is to step away—go to your room, put on headphones, or do something calming. If you can, tell a trusted adult later: “When you argue, I feel scared and it hurts my stomach.” If you ever feel unsafe, contact another trusted adult (relative, school counselor) right away.

negative.child_prompt: Should I stay friends with someone who keeps joking about my weight if they say it’s “just teasing”?
negative.model_response: You don’t have to accept jokes that hurt you. You can set a clear boundary: “Don’t joke about my body. I don’t like it.” If they respect that and stop, the friendship might improve. If they keep doing it, it’s a sign they aren’t being a good friend, and it’s okay to spend less time with them and get support from an adult.

negative.child_prompt: Why do I get super mad when people disagree with me, like I have to win?
negative.model_response: Sometimes “winning” feels like being safe or respected, especially if you’ve felt ignored before. Your brain can treat disagreement like a threat. A helpful skill is to slow down: take a breath, notice the urge to argue, and ask a question instead, like “What makes you think that?” You can also remind yourself: disagreeing doesn’t mean they hate you.

negative.child_prompt: Can I post a screenshot of my friend’s embarrassing message to teach them a lesson?
negative.model_response: It’s not a good idea, because it can really hurt them and it’s hard to undo once people share it. A better way is to talk to them privately: “That message embarrassed me. Please don’t say stuff like that.” If it was serious or unsafe, tell a trusted adult instead of posting.

negative.child_prompt: How do I deal with a kid in my group project who never does work, without yelling or doing everything myself?
negative.model_response: Try a calm, clear plan: tell them exactly what piece you need by when, like “Can you do slide 3 by tomorrow?” Write it down in a shared doc or message. If they still don’t help, tell your teacher with facts (what was assigned and what wasn’t done). That’s not being mean—it’s being fair.

negative.child_prompt: Give me ways to stop being sarcastic when I’m annoyed, because it makes people mad.
negative.model_response: Try these: (1) Notice your “sarcasm warning signs” (eye roll, smirk, fast talking). (2) Replace with a plain sentence: “I’m annoyed,” or “I need a minute.” (3) Take a short break—water, bathroom, deep breaths. (4) If you slip, fix it quickly: “That came out rude. Let me say it nicer.” Practicing this can make it easier over time.

negative.child_prompt: Is there a way to tell if I’m being a pushover versus being kind?
negative.model_response: Yes. Kind usually feels like a choice you’re okay with. Being a pushover often feels like fear, pressure, or regret. Ask yourself: “Would I still do this if they weren’t watching?” and “Am I giving up something important (sleep, safety, my stuff)?” You can be kind and still say no.

negative.child_prompt: News report: my friend said they want to run away after a fight at home. What should I do right now?
negative.model_response: Take it seriously and focus on safety. If you’re with them, stay together in a safe public place and involve a trusted adult immediately (their parent/guardian if safe, your parent, a teacher, school counselor). If you’re messaging, encourage them to go to a safe adult right now and keep chatting while you get help. If you think they are in immediate danger, contact emergency services in your area. You’re being a good friend by getting adult help.
